I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Kyrgyz Republic became a member of the Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) on 12 
August 2015.1 The country’s accession to the EEU is expected to have diverse and significant 
implications for the country’s economy. With the EEU’s combined population of about 180 
million and its larger market, the intended free movement of goods, services, capital, and labor, 
and  elimination  of  customs  controls  and  nontrade  barriers,  the  EEU  presents  significant 
economic  opportunities  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic’s  economic  policies, 
regulations, and the legal framework need to be adjusted to those of the EEU, and the potential 
economic and social costs of the accession need to be minimized. It is in this context that the 
Government of the Kyrgyz Republic has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide the proposed technical assistance (TA),2 which was included into the country operations 
business plan, 2015–2017.3  
 
2.  Consultations with representatives of the government, the country’s private sector and 
think tanks, and development partners took place during the reconnaissance and fact-finding 
phases of TA preparation.4 The government expressed its concurrence with the TA design as 
described in the August 2015 fact-finding mission’s memorandum of understanding. The design 
and monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Excluding  the  small  island  states,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  one  of  ADB’s  smallest 
developing member countries in terms of land area, population, and size of the economy. The 
country’s  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  is  extremely  volatile,  reflecting  significant 
dependency on several factors and vulnerability to external shocks.5 The country has strong 
economic ties with the Russian Federation, through remittances of the Kyrgyz workers, currency 
movements, trade, and investment channels.6 
 
4.  The Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU occurs in the challenging internal and 
external economic environment, including economic slowdowns in the Russian Federation and 
in Kazakhstan.7 Both developments exert a downward pressure on the Kyrgyz economy, largely 
through the remittances and trade channels. Remittances started to fall 22.5% in the last quarter 
                                                
1  The treaty establishing the EEU was signed on 29 May 2014 by the presidents of Belarus, Kazakhstan, and the 
Russian Federation, and came into force on 1 January 2015. Armenia became a member of the EEU from 2 
January 2015. The Agreement on the Kyrgyz Republic’s Accession to the EEU was concluded on 23 December 
2014, and its final protocols finalized on 8 May 2015. Subsequently, these legal documents were ratified by all EEU 
members’ parliaments.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 September 2015.  
3   ADB. 2014. Country Operations Business Plan: Kyrgyz Republic, 2015–2017. Manila. 
4   Among other relevant development partner assistance to the Kyrgyz Republic are the bilateral assistance on 
elimination of customs controls by Kazakhstan and the Russian Federation; an International Monetary Fund (IMF) 
assessment of the impact of the accession to the EEU; and various ongoing projects by the World Bank Group, 
United Nations Development Programme, and United States Agency for International Development aimed at 
business support, promotion of agricultural and nonagricultural value chains and exports, food safety, and others. 
5  For example, real GDP growth in the last 5 years recorded: –0.5% (2010), 6.0% (2011), –0.1% (2012), 10.5% 
(2013), and 3.6% (2014). The gold sector is a key element of the economy, accounting for more than 40% of 
exports and more than 20% of industrial production, with the Kumtor Gold Company alone accounting for 8% of 
GDP. 
6  The Russian Federation employs up to 1 million Kyrgyz citizens (about one-fifth of the population). Remittances 
from the Russian Federation—an important source of private consumption—are estimated at 25% of GDP. 
7  The Russian GDP is expected to decline by 3.5% in 2015, and Kazakhstan’s economic growth to slow down from 
the earlier 4.8% forecast to 2% in 2015. It is also expected that the feed-through effects from the Russian 
recession on migrant workers’ transfers are expected to last longer this time than in 2009.

2 
 
of 2014, and declined by more than 25% in the first half of 2015 (year-on-year). The sharp 
depreciation of the Russian ruble and the devaluation of the Kazakh tenge have put pressure on 
the som, which depreciated against the US dollar by 20% in 2014, and by 14.5% since the 
beginning of this year, resulting in higher inflation. Together with the lower expected gold 
production in 2015, the Kyrgyz Republic’s real GDP growth is forecast to fall to 1.7%, down from 
3.6% in 2014.8  
 
5.  The undiversified economy, driven mainly by gold production and remittances-backed 
private consumption, limits economic opportunities at home and leads to high unemployment. 
Given the country’s limited economies of scale and significant economic vulnerabilities, regional 
economic integration is essential for the Kyrgyz Republic’s economic prospects and its people’s 
livelihoods. 
 
6.  The Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU will impact the country’s economy via the 
trade, migration, and investment channels.9 For the Kyrgyz Republic, the key issues include the 
elimination of customs controls at intra-EEU borders, an increase in duties on imports from 
outside the EEU, the adoption of the EEU technical regulations and standards, and the supply 
response from the specific sectors of the Kyrgyz economy, in particular, agriculture and food 
processing, garment, and the re-export sector.10 In addition, the Kyrgyz Republic’s commitments 
and obligations under the World Trade Organization, of which the country is a member since 
1998, would need to be reconsidered in light of the EEU membership.  
 
7.  The recurrent theme in the discussions with key stakeholders during the preparation of 
the proposed TA was the ensuing uncertainty as to the implications of the country’s accession 
to the EEU. The following emerged as key issues related to the country’s accession to the EEU: 
(i)  the  economic  opportunities  and  risks  to  the  country’s  economy;  (ii)  the  considerable 
challenges during this transition period; (iii) the central and local government agencies’ weak 
capacities related to the accession to the EEU; and (iv) the need for better and wider public 
awareness of the issues pertaining to the accession to the EEU, especially among the country’s 
business sector. 
 
III. THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The proposed TA will support the Kyrgyz Republic following its accession to the EEU, 
with the view of capturing the economic opportunities presented by the EEU’s larger market and 
its free movement of goods, services, capital, and labor, and minimizing the potential economic 
and  social  costs  of  the  accession.  The  impact  of  the  proposed  TA  will  be  the  improved 
prospects of the Kyrgyz Republic’s economy within the framework of the EEU. The outcome of 
the TA will be the improved capacity and capability of the Kyrgyz Republic’s government to 
                                                
8   In response to the unfolding economic difficulties and to help offset the impact of the Russian economic slowdown 
and other external factors, the government requested the IMF to provide an extended credit facility, and the IMF 
approved the $92.4 million financing package in April 2015. IMF. 2015. Kyrgyz Republic: Request for a Three-Year 
Arrangement Under the Extended Credit Facility. Washington, DC. 
9  These implications should be distinguished from the macroeconomic shock facing the Kyrgyz economy caused by 
the 2014’s Russian ruble devaluation and the economic slowdowns in the Russian Federation and Kazakhstan. 
10  Re-export of goods, mainly from the People’s Republic of China and Turkey to other countries, comprises a 
significant part of the Kyrgyz economy, and contributes to employment and income.

3 
 
formulate and adopt sound economic and social policies pertinent to the country’s accession to 
the EEU.11 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The  above  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  achieved  through  the  following  outputs  and 
activities. 
 
10.  Output 1: Policy advice and analytical support on the Eurasian Economic Union 
accession  issues.  These  will  include  policy  advice  and  analytical  support  for  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic’s government on strategic issues, to ensure that the Eurasian Economic Commission’s 
decisions do not have a detrimental effect, and are in the interests of the country’s development. 
Specific issues for analytical and monitoring support include macroeconomic impacts, adoption 
of the common external tariff of the EEU, impact on trade, labor and investments, coordination 
on specific technical regulations, and impact on selected sectors of the economy.12  
 
11.  Output 2: Improved methodology, coverage, and collection of statistical data to 
monitor the impact of the country’s accession to the Eurasian Economic Union. The 
Kyrgyz Republic’s national statistics have limited methodology, scope, and coverage, severely 
hindering  a  routine  monitoring  of  economic  developments.13 This  component  will  focus  on 
improving the methodology, coverage, and collection of data on “mutual trade” in the Kyrgyz 
Republic, compatible and “mirror” trade statistics with EEU member countries, better statistics 
on labor migration and remittances, and other indicators required for the meaningful monitoring 
of the impact of the Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU.14 
 
12.  Output  3:  Tailored  training  and  public  awareness  programs  to  capture  the 
economic  opportunities  presented  by  the  Eurasian  Economic  Union. To  address  the 
dearth  of  information  on  changes  in  economic  policies,  regulations,  technical  standards, 
legislative documents, etc., both among the public and private sectors, which hinders their 
adaptation to the new realities of the economy, this component will focus on training and public 
awareness programs specifically tailored for key stakeholders: central and local governments, 
small and medium-sized enterprises, individual entrepreneurs, business associations, and the 
country’s think tanks.15  
 
13.  The following key risks to the TA project’s implementation need to be considered: (i) 
political instability that can derail the initiated economic reforms; (ii) the weak voice of the 
Kyrgyz Republic in the supranational bodies of the EEU, which is dominated by larger EEU 
                                                
11 The TA’s sustainability will be one of its key principles, in the sense that the TA’s outcome will go beyond the EEU 
accession issues. 
12 Analytical  support  will  focus  on  systemic  issues,  such  as  the  development  of  methodologies  for  various 
assessments and appropriate training of Ministry of Economy (MOE) staff. For example, the TA will develop a 
methodology for assessing the impact of the Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU on various sectors of the 
economy (including agriculture, textile industry, construction materials, and others), and will conduct a pilot 
assessment for a selected sector of the economy; or a methodology for regulatory impact analysis of regulations of 
the Eurasian Economic Commission on the Kyrgyz economy. 
13  Attempts at formal economic modeling and scenario analysis (for example, within a computable general equilibrium 
framework, a standard tool for assessing general economic impacts) are constrained in the case of the Kyrgyz 
Republic. 
14 “Mutual trade” denotes exports and imports between the EEU member countries. 
15 Examples include the need to address unawareness among the country’s businesses engaged in re-export and 
other trade operations regarding changes in the tax administration procedures associated with accession to the 
EEU, or establishment of a call center for clarification of various technical (for example, phytosanitary and 
veterinary) regulatory issues for companies and business associations.

4 
 
member countries; and (iii) frequent turnover of government staff that may result in ineffective 
use of policy advice and recommendations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space and supplies, and other in-kind 
contributions. The Ministry of Economy (MOE) and other relevant government agencies and 
departments will provide the required materials, information, and data. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The MOE is the state agency responsible for the overall coordination of the Kyrgyz 
Republic’s accession matters, and it will be the executing agency for the TA. The TA will be 
administered by ADB. Several MOE departments and divisions will be involved in the TA, 
including the Department on Accession to the EEU and the World Trade Organization Issues, 
the Department of Technical Regulations and Metrology, the Macroeconomic Department, the 
Department of Strategic Planning and Regional Development, and the Department of External 
Aid Coordination. The MOE will assign the TA coordinator (the deputy minister in charge of the 
EEU accession) to support and coordinate all TA activities, and to assist with absorption of the 
TA outcomes into the MOE’s work and activities. 
 
16.  A TA steering committee will be established under the chairmanship of the minister of 
economy,  and  will  comprise  senior  government  officials  from  the  executing  agency,  the 
Government Staff Department, Ministry of Finance, National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz 
Republic, and other relevant agencies. The steering committee will oversee TA implementation 
and recommend adjustments to the TA scope, if needed. During the TA implementation, the 
MOE  will  coordinate  activities  of  all  relevant  stakeholders,  including  the  central  and  local 
authorities involved in the project, as well as the activities of other development partners in this 
area. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2016 until December 2017. 
The  TA  will  engage  12  person-months  of  international  and  32  person-months  of  national 
consulting services in the field of macroeconomics, international trade and regional economic 
integration, statistics, and others. The outline terms of reference for the consulting services is in 
Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged on an individual basis,16 and a national consulting 
firm will be engaged to implement the training and public awareness component. Resource 
persons (to be engaged for round tables, seminars, and study tours) will be recruited from ADB 
member countries using the single-source selection method. All consultants will be recruited in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). All procurement of goods will be conducted in accordance with ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines  (2015,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  equipment  will  be  used  for 
implementation of the TA and will be transferred to the executing agency at TA completion. All 
disbursement under the TA will be carried out in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
                                                
16 The preliminary search for potential firms in ADB member countries with suitable expertise and experience in the 
EEU, its policies, regulations, and institutions, has identified no such firms.

5 
 
18.  A series of round table discussions and workshops will be held under the TA, with 
participation  of  external  experts,  analytical  organizations,  development  partners,  and  other 
relevant stakeholders. An evaluation of the TA outputs and outcomes will be carried out at the 
end of the TA and reflected in the TA completion report. 
 
19.  The TA will be monitored through biannual review of the TA implementation, involving 
submissions of progress reports by the consultants, and consultations with the government 
during TA review missions.  
   
IV. THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  Accession to the  Eurasian  Economic  Union—
Capturing the Opportunities and Addressing the Risks, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

f  Includes rent of venue and other facilities, facilitators, background materials, and other related costs. 
g  Includes rent of venue and other facilities, training materials, food and beverages, and other related costs. 
h  Includes the cost of translation, office supplies, and advertisement and publications.  
Source: ADB estimates.

10   Appendix 3           
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will engage 12 person-months of international and 32 
person-months of national consulting services in the field of macroeconomics, international 
trade and regional economic integration, statistics, and others. All consultants will be recruited in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time).  
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Macroeconomist and team leader (6 person-months, intermittent). The team leader 
will lead the international and national specialists and be responsible for all TA outputs. The 
team leader will be a macroeconomist with preferably 15 years of international experience, 
including in economic development and regional integration affairs. A working knowledge of 
Russian language and work in the former Soviet Union countries would be desirable. The team 
leader  will  be  responsible  for  preparation  and  submission  of  all  TA  progress  reports  and 
documentation. 
 
3.  To maximize the opportunities offered to the Kyrgyz Republic by the membership in the 
Eurasian Economic Union (EEU), and to alleviate potential costs and risks during the transition 
period associated with accession to the EEU, the macroeconomist, in collaboration with other 
consultants, will provide support and advice to government agencies on the following issues: 
(i)  development of methodology for analyzing the impact of the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
accession  to  the  EEU  on  the  selected  sectors  of  the  economy  (including 
agriculture  and  food  processing,  textile  industry,  construction  materials 
production,  trade,  construction,  and  others);  support  in  carrying  out  a  pilot 
analysis of one of the sectors chosen by agreement with the Ministry of Economy 
(MOE); 
(ii)  methodological support in establishing a system of regulatory impact analysis of 
regulations and policies of the Eurasian Economic Commission (EEC) and other 
bodies of the EEU on the Kyrgyz economy, development of principles and rules 
for determining the priority directions for the analysis of the regulatory impact 
analysis of acts and decisions of the EEU, undertaking a pilot regulatory impact 
analysis of the most significant decisions, and training of MOE staff and other 
relevant agencies in such an analysis (together with the international consultant 
on  international  trade  and  regional  integration  and  national  consultants  on 
macroeconomics, legal, and social issues); 
(iii)  methodological support in the adaptation of the system of macroeconomic and 
budgetary  forecasting  to  procedural  interaction  with  the  EEC  (e.g.,  using 
consensus forecast of oil prices, global economic growth, imports, and other 
exogenous variables, modification of the method of budgetary forecasting);  
(iv)  development of opportunities for exchange of experiences between relevant staff 
of the Kyrgyz Republic government and their colleagues from other EEU member 
states  working  in  the  field  of  macroeconomic  management,  statistics,  tax 
administration and other fields (together with an expert on statistics and other 
members of the group); and 
(v)  organization of expert discussions, round tables, and other types of professional 
and public debate to discuss and disseminate the analytical products of the TA 
(together with other members of the group).

Appendix 3  11 
4.  Economist  on  international  trade  and  regional  integration  (3  person-months, 
intermittent). The consultant will preferably have at least 15 years of international experience, 
including in international trade, economic development, World Trade Organization issues, and 
regional integration. A working knowledge of Russian language and work in the former Soviet 
Union countries would be desirable. The consultant will support the government on the following 
issues (in addition to those mentioned in the tasks of the macroeconomist above): 
(i)  development of methodology for the analysis of the common external tariff of the 
EEU and its dynamics; 
(ii)  development of methodology for analyzing the impact of changes in domestic 
economic policies in the Russian Federation, Kazakhstan, and other countries of 
the EEU, on the Kyrgyz economy (e.g., impact of the Russian import substitution 
policy or Kazakhstan's policy of intensive agriculture development on the Kyrgyz 
export to these countries); 
(iii)  analytical  support  for  issues  of  nontariff  regulation  (veterinary,  sanitary  and 
phytosanitary,  and  technical  types  of  control),  e.g.,  development  of 
recommendations—on the basis of cost–benefit and institutional analyses—on 
introduction of new laboratories, certification procedures, and of adaptation of 
businesses to the new or modified requirements; and 
(iv)  development of methodology for analysis of external shocks that have a direct 
impact on the EEU members, and through them, on the Kyrgyz Republic (e.g., 
the fall in global oil prices, western sanctions, etc.). 
 
5.  Statistics expert (3 person-months, intermittent). The consultant will have at least 10 
years of professional experience, including in statistics on international trade and balance of 
payments, labor migration, and others. A working knowledge of Russian language and work in 
the former Soviet Union countries would be desirable. The consultant will work closely with 
other team members in delivering the TA outputs. The consultant will support the government 
on the following issues (in addition to those mentioned in the tasks of the macroeconomist 
above): 
(i)  methodological support for development and implementation of information and 
recording system of the Kyrgyz Republic’s imports and exports from and to the 
EEU countries of goods by rail, air, and road transport modes for the State Tax 
Service, the State Customs Service, and the National Statistical Committee; 
(ii)  analysis of the effectiveness or assessment of the ongoing National Statistics 
Committee’s work on “mutual trade” statistics between the Kyrgyz Republic and 
other EEU members; development of recommendations to improve the system, 
taking into account all possible sources of data, including the "mirror" statistics; 
and 
(iii)  development of recommendations for improving the labor migration statistics, 
including the clarification of the conceptual framework (e.g., who constitutes a 
migrant worker), improving accounting of foreign workers in the country, and 
exploring possibilities of using the European Union and other regional integration 
arrangements’ experiences in labor movement statistics. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
6.  Macroeconomist  and  deputy  team  leader  (12  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist  will  undertake  relevant  macroeconomic  work,  coordinate  the  work  of  national 
consultants, and be responsible for interaction of the consulting team with the government 
bodies of the Kyrgyz Republic. The consultant will be an expert in macroeconomics with at least

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
15 years of experience in government and international development projects. The consultant 
will support the government on the following issues: 
(i)  a pilot analysis of the impact of the Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU on 
one of the sectors of the economy, selected in consultation with MOE (together 
with the international consultant and macroeconomist); 
(ii)  a pilot regulatory impact analysis of most significant acts and decisions of the 
EEC  (economic  aspects);  development  of  recommendations  on  institutional, 
procedural, and operational issues of regulatory impact analyses of the EEC 
decisions in the Kyrgyz government; training of relevant MOE and other agencies’ 
staff  in  such  an  analysis  (together  with  the  international  consultant  and 
macroeconomist and national consultants on legal and social issues); and 
(iii)  support for  the  adaptation  of the  systems  of macroeconomic  and  budgetary 
forecasting to the interaction procedures with the EEC. 
 
7.  Social and labor market expert (6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have at 
least  10  years  of  experience  in  government  or  international  development  projects.  The 
consultant will support the government on the following issues: 
(i)  a pilot analysis of the impact of the Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU on 
one of the sectors of the economy selected in consultation with MOE (social 
aspects), and 
(ii)  a pilot regulatory impact analysis of most significant acts and/or decisions of the 
EEC on social aspects of the Kyrgyz economy. 
 
8.  Legal expert (6 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have at least 10 years of 
legal experience in government or international development projects, as well as experience of 
working on harmonization of the legislation of the Kyrgyz Republic with the legal framework of 
the EEU. The legal expert should have strong knowledge of the EEU framework, policies, rules 
and regulations, including those for accession; strong knowledge of the Kyrgyz Republic’s 
policies, laws, rules, and regulations that may be affected by the accession; and experience in 
accession to, or other similar integration with, regional or other international arrangements 
similar  to the  EEU,  including  on revising  legal frameworks,  laws,  rules  and  regulations  to 
conform to, adapt to, or accommodate the regional or international arrangements acceded to. 
The consultant will support the government on the following issues: 
(i)  a pilot regulatory impact analysis of most significant acts and/or decisions of the 
EEC (legal aspects); and 
(ii)  an analysis of changes in the investment and business climate of the Kyrgyz 
Republic in the context of the EEU and development of recommendations for its 
improvement (together with the international consultant and macroeconomist). 
 
9.  International trade and international regional integration expert (4 person-months, 
intermittent). The expert will have at least 10 years of experience in government or international 
development projects. The consultant will support the government on the following issues: 
(i)  development of methodology and analysis tools of the common external tariff and 
its dynamics; 
(ii)  a pilot analysis of the impact of changes in the domestic economic policies of the 
Russian  Federation,  Kazakhstan,  and  other  EEU  countries  on  the  Kyrgyz 
economy; and 
(iii)  a pilot analysis of external shocks that have a direct impact on the EEU members, 
and indirect impact on the Kyrgyz Republic.

Appendix 3  13 
10.  Statistics expert (4 person-months, intermittent). The expert will have at least 10 years 
of experience in government or international development projects. The consultant will support 
the government on the following issues: 
(i)  development  and  implementation  of  information  system  for  recording  Kyrgyz 
imports and exports of goods from and to the EEU; 
(ii)  assessment and improvement of the statistical system of “mutual trade” with the 
members with the EEU; and 
(iii)  improvement of labor migration and remittances statistics. 
 
11.  Training and public awareness specialists. A consulting firm will be engaged under 
an output-based contract, and will work closely with other TA team members, government 
counterparts, and other stakeholders on coordinating and organizing the training and public 
awareness programs related to the Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU. The consultant will 
support the government on the following issues: 
(i)  organization  of  training  of  (a)  entrepreneurs  and  business  associations;  (b) 
government staff; (c) representatives of civil society and media; and (d) other 
groups as required, on new rules and regulations in the context of the EEU, 
including on changes in the taxation regime, customs procedures, sanitary and 
phytosanitary measures, technical regulations, statistics, and others; and 
(ii)  public awareness campaign on the conditions and practical implications of the 
Kyrgyz Republic’s accession to the EEU, preparation of relevant television and 
radio programs, and publication and dissemination of various analytical materials 
and information. 
 
12.  All national consultants will participate in the interagency interaction and cooperation, in 
line with their main expertise, and in discussions of the analytical products under the TA. 
  
C.   Short-term Experts and Resource Persons 
 
13.  Short-term experts and/or resource persons will be engaged to prepare presentations 
and analytical materials on specific topics, and to act as discussants or panelists on related 
policy issues.
